title.value: Questions Are All You Need to Train a Dense Passage Retriever
title.justification: This is the title displayed at the top of the paper.
title.quote: Questions Are All You Need to Train a Dense Passage Retriever

extractions.description: The paper introduces ART, a new corpus-level autoencoding approach to dense passage retrieval that doesn't require labeled training data. By using a passage-retrieval autoencoding scheme, ART allows effective unsupervised learning of passage and question encoders. The study demonstrates ART's superior performance on various QA retrieval benchmarks, showcasing its potential to replace traditional supervised retrievers without the need for custom hard-negative mining and dataset-specific losses.

type.justification: The paper presents experimental results and performance comparisons on various benchmarks to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ART method.
type.quote: Extensive experiments demonstrate that ART obtains state-of-the-art results on multiple QA retrieval benchmarks with only generic initialization from a pretrained language model, removing the need for labeled data and task-specific losses.

name.justification: The primary focus is on developing a new method for dense passage retrieval, which is a core task in Information Retrieval.
name.quote: We introduce ART, a new corpus-level autoencoding approach for training dense retrieval models that does not require any labeled training data.

name.justification: The paper focuses on retrieval methods for open-domain tasks like Open QA.
name.quote: Given an input question, ART first retrieves a small set of possible evidences passages. It then reconstructs the original question by attending to these passages (see Figure 1 for an overview).

name.justification: The methodologies and tasks involved, such as question answering and passage retrieval, are integral parts of Natural Language Processing.
name.quote: We introduce ART, a new corpus-level autoencoding approach for training dense retrieval models that does not require any labeled training data.

name.justification: The model introduced and primarily discussed in the paper is ART, which stands for Autoencoding-based Retriever Training.
name.quote: We propose ART: Autoencoding-based Retriever Training which only assumes access to sets of unpaired questions and passages.

is_contributed.justification: The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of ART.
is_contributed.quote: In this paper, we introduce the first unsupervised method, based on a new corpus-level autoencoding approach, that can match or surpass strong supervised performance levels with no labeled training data or task-specific losses.

is_executed.justification: The experiments mention that the embeddings and retrieval processes are performed on accelerators such as GPUs.
is_executed.quote: As the selection operation requires performing inner-product with millions of passage embeddings, this can be efficiently performed on accelerators such as GPUs.

is_compared.justification: ART is compared with various existing models in terms of performance on several benchmarks, showing its superiority in most cases.
is_compared.quote: By simply using questions from the training set, ART outperforms models like DPR by an average of 5 points absolute in top-20 and 4 points absolute in top-100 accuracy.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no specific referenced paper for ART as it is the primary contribution of this document.
